RECORD.TEXT: 145027124 YC 08849209 982750 3/15/1997 12:00:00 AM CHOLELITHIASIS Signed DIS Admission Date : 03/15/1997 Report Status : Signed Discharge Date : 03/20/1997 HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS : The patient is a 69-year-old woman with a history of gallstones diagnosed in 1995 , who presented to the Emergency Room with the complaint of severe right upper quadrant pain . The patient experienced minimal nausea and vomiting . She denied fevers and chills . She had not taken any pain medicine given that she has a sensitivity to narcotics . She denied any diarrhea . She had no anorexia . Last bowel movement was last night and was normal . The patient denied any radiation of the pain . She noted that it became increasingly more painful during the course of the day . She also noticed that she had intermittent right upper quadrant pain consistent with her previous episodes of cholelithiasis and biliary colic over the past few months . PAST MEDICAL HISTORY : Significant for hypothyroidism and cholelithiasis . She has had no previous surgery . She has acute sensitivity to narcotics with mental status changes . Her medicines were on admission were Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg once a day , Synthroid 100 mcg once a day , pravastatin 20 mg once a day . PHYSICAL EXAMINATION : Afebrile at 98.4 , vital signs within normal limits . Overall , the patient was moderately uncomfortable . Focused exam showed a soft abdomen , but was tender in the right upper quadrant to mild to moderate palpation . There was guarding , but no evidence of rebound . Rectal exam was guaiac negative and non-tender . LABORATORY DATA : BUN 13 , creatinine 0.7 , white count 11 , hematocrit 41.2 , total bilirubin 0.4 , direct bilirubin 0.1 , LFTs were otherwise within normal limits . Urinalysis was negative . An ultrasound was obtained in the Emergency Room that showed multiple small gallstones approximately 1 cm in size . There was no gallbladder wall thickening , no paracholecystic fluid . Electrocardiogram showed normal sinus rhythm with no acute changes . Chest x-ray showed no acute disease . IMPRESSION : This is a 69-year-old woman with acute cholecystitis . There was no evidence of common bile duct obstruction . The plan was for the patient to be admitted to the Er Monter Hospital for IV antibiotic for follow-up laparoscopic cholecystectomy . The patient was kept NPO on IV hydration and pain medicine . HOSPITAL COURSE : The patient did well and remained afebrile and responded well to IV hydration and antibiotics . The patient had good pain control with intermittent Demerol . She consented for laparoscopic cholecystectomy . Preoperative laboratory studies were unremarkable . On 3/18/97 the patient was taken to the Operating Room , where laparoscopic cholecystectomy was performed . She had minimal blood loss and had a JP drain placed in the gallbladder fossa . The patient was taken to Recovery Room in stable condition . She was kept on IV fluids and IV antibiotics for 24 hours . The postoperative course was unremarkable . She remained afebrile and wounds were clean , dry and intact without any evidence of infection . The patient 's JP drain was removed after she had started her diet . DISPOSITION : The patient was discharged to home on 3/20/97 . At that time she was discharged on all previous medicines that she had been admitted with , plus Percocet 1 to 2 tablets q 3 hours PRN pain . The patient was discharged in good condition with no restrictions placed on her diet . Her activity was as tolerated . She was to follow-up with Dr. Vital in the Villehardsotan Community Memorial Hospital on one week . Dictated By : MA A. PIERNREUKOTEFILLE , M.D. KC89 Attending : RYBAM T.
